Bestiary.name: Bestiary
Bestiary.text:
Bestiary

This section contains animals, humanoids, and monsters found throughout Golarion.

Some entries have elite or alternative roles listed. These take the form of upgrades to the base profile. Simply add the upgrades listed to turn the base profile into the elite variant (the base bugbear into a bugbear raider, for example).

If the creature has more than one available upgrade, the advancements are cumulative, so to apply the first before you apply the second (so to make a bugbear executioner, take the base bugbear profile, add the bugbear raider improvements and then add the executioner upgrades as well).

Wild Card Monsters

Creatures noted with this symbol are @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Cards and Extras}. They roll a Wild Die with Trait checks and can take three @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} before being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}.

Iconic creatures and "bosses," such as @Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Red Dragon, Adult]{adult dragons} or @Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Lich]{liches}, are almost always Wild Cards.

Named creatures are often Wild Cards as well, such as the ogre Jaagrath Kreeg in the Rise of the Runelords Adventure Path or any of his named kin.

Groups of creatures are often led by a Wild Card as well, such as a pack of @Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Dog/Wolf]{wolves} led by a Wild Card "alpha."

Which creatures are and aren't Wild Cards is up to the GM and how challenging you want a threat to be.

Auroch.name: Auroch
Auroch.text:
Auroch

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Auroch]{Link to Actor}

This large, horned bull has a dirty black hide and an aggressive temper. Its horns are wide and sharp, and they usually travel in herds. Various breeds inhabit the wilds of Golarion, from the Nesmian Plains of Nirmathas to the Storval Plateau in Varisia.

Type: Neutral Animal (Auroch)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d8, Strength d12+1, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d6, Notice d6

Pace: 7; Parry: 5; Toughness: 9

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Horns: Str+d6.
  • Size 3: Aurochs weigh just under a ton.
  • Stampede: Anyone caught in a stampede must Evade as an action on their turn or take 2d6 damage. Add a bonus d6 if the victim Critically Fails to Evade. This may last for multiple rounds with a large herd.

Ghost.name: Ghost
Ghost.text:
Ghost

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Ghost]{Link to Actor}

A ghost is the spirit of a mortal creature that returns from death to haunt the living or fulfill some unfinished business. They can’t— or won’t—leave a specific location on the Material @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04theplanes00000]{Plane} until they complete some specific task or meet some condition.

Type: Evil Undead (Ghost)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d8, Strength d6, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d6, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d8, Notice d8, Stealth d8

Pace: —; Parry: 6; Toughness: 6

Edges: —

Gear: Thrown objects (Str+d4).

Special Abilities:

  • Corrupting Touch: Str+2d6.
  • Darkvision: Ghosts ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Ethereal: Ghosts can become invisible and immaterial at will and can only be harmed by magical attacks.
  • Fear (−2): Ghosts cause Fear checks at −2 when they let themselves be seen.
  • Flight: Pace 12.
  • Rejuvenation: Even after it is “destroyed” a spirit will restore itself in 2d4 days. The only way to permanently destroy a ghost is to set right whatever is preventing it from moving on.

Languages: Common.

Ghoul.name: Ghoul
Ghoul.text:
Ghoul

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Ghoul]{Link to Actor}

These undead creatures resemble whatever humanoid form they had before they came into unlife. At a distance, observers might mistake them for living creatures, but up close, their undead state is obvious.

Ghouls always appear emaciated and sickly. These characteristics belie their true threat to the living, as they can infect humanoids and turn them into ghouls. Necromancers can create these vile creatures as well. These undead exist in a constant state of hunger; their desire for flesh motivates most of their behavior, although they possess a modicum of intelligence.

Type: Evil Undead (Ghoul)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6, Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d6, Notice d8, Stealth d8

Pace: 6; Parry: 5; Toughness: 7

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Bite/Claws: Str+d4, AP 2.
  • Hardy: A second Shaken result in combat doesn't cause a Wound to ghouls.
  • Infection: Anyone Shaken or Wounded by a ghoul’s bite attack must make a Vigor roll (at –2 with a raise on the attack) or contract ghoul fever. Ghoul fever is a Lethal disease, requiring a Vigor roll each day to prevent taking a Wound. Anyone killed by ghoul fever rises from the dead at midnight, becoming a ghoul themselves.
  • Paralysis: Anyone Wounded by a ghoul’s natural attack must make a Vigor roll or be Stunned. Elves are immune to this effect.
  • Undead: +2 Toughness; +2 to recover from being Shaken; no additional damage from Called Shots; ignores 1 point of Wound penalties; doesn’t breathe; immune to disease and poison; ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.

Languages: Common.

Giant.name: Giant
Giant.text:
Giant

This section details several varieties of giantkind found on Golarion. These humanoids all share a common characteristic—they are all massive compared to humans.

All giants speak the Giant language, while some also understand other tongues.

Common Abilities

  • Ancestry (Giant): Low Light Vision, Reach 1, Swat.

Cloud Giant.name: Cloud Giant
Cloud Giant.text:
Cloud Giant

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Cloud Giant]{Link to Actor}

These majestic giants dwell in the highest mountains on Golarion. Their skin ranges in color from milky white to powder blue. They dress in the finest clothing and jewelry available. They are 20 feet tall and weigh almost 5,500 pounds.

Cloud giants are divided into two distinct societies at odds with each other. The Good faction believes in peace and harmony, preferring to coexist with all giantkind and other humanoid societies. Their Evil counterparts live in seclusion in their mountain lairs, viewing other peoples as mere objects to exploit or ignore.

Type: Evil or Good Humanoid (Cloud Giant)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d6, Spirit d8, Strength d12+5, Vigor d12

Skills: Athletics d8, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d10, Intimidation d8, Notice d8, Performance d6, Persuasion d6, Stealth d4

Pace: 8; Parry: 7; Toughness: 16 (3)

Edges: Sweep

Gear: Gargantuan morningstar (Str+d10), chain shirt (+2).

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +1: Tough skin.
  • Hardy: Cloud giants do not suffer a Wound from being Shaken twice.
  • Innate Powers: Minor fly (levitate up and down only).
  • Obscuring Mist: Cloud giants can create a supernatural mist in a Large Blast Template at will. The mist lasts 10 minutes and subtracts 2 from any vision-based Trait roll made through or within the mist. This stacks with Illumination penalties, and is not negated by Infravision, Darkvision, or Low Light Vision.
  • Rock Throwing: Giants are exceptionally good at throwing rocks, and can even throw at Extreme Range. Damage Str+d12, Range 20/40/80, Heavy Weapon.
  • Size 5 (Large): 20' tall, +1 Wound.

Languages: Common, Giant.

Fire Giant.name: Fire Giant
Fire Giant.text:
Fire Giant

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Fire Giant]{Link to Actor}

These lumbering giants have short stumpy legs, broad chests, and powerful, muscular arms. They are 16 feet tall and weigh upwards of 7,000 pounds. Their hair and beard seem to be made of fire. They prefer hot locations—the hotter, the better—from the Mindspin Mountains of Avistan, to the volcanic regions of the Darklands.

Fire giants are the most rigid and militaristic of all the giants. They constantly train for war and employ brutal tactics on anyone and everyone that gets in their way. Their rigid command structure is complete with soldiers, officers, and even generals, and they obey orders from their kings unquestioningly.

Type: Evil Humanoid (Fire Giant)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d12+3, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d8, Common Knowledge d4, Fighting d8, Intimidation d10, Notice d8

Pace: 7; Parry: 6 ; Toughness: 16 (4)

Edges: Sweep

Gear: Large greatsword (Str+d10, AP 2), chain shirt (+3).

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +1: Fire-tempered skin.
  • Environmental Weakness: Cold.
  • Immunity: Fire.
  • Rock Throwing: Giants are exceptionally good at throwing rocks, and can even throw at Extreme Range. Damage Str+d12, Range 20/40/80, Heavy Weapon.
  • Size 5 (Large): 16' tall, +1 Wound.

Languages: Common, Giant.

Frost Giant.name: Frost Giant
Frost Giant.text:
Frost Giant

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Frost Giant]{Link to Actor}

These giants usually have frosty-white or icy-blue skin and long braided hair. They are 15 feet tall and weigh almost 2,800 pounds. They dwell in the coldest environments of Golarion, such as the northern reaches of Avistan and the Crown of the World. Their lairs typically include pets such as winter wolves, young white dragons, and mammoths.

Frost giants are feared by other humanoids because of their battle lust and habit of taking captives. These giants survive by hunting, foraging, and raiding for supplies and slaves. They perceive other peoples purely as commodities.

They prefer to ambush their prey, throwing heavy rocks from afar or starting an avalanche before engaging with their greataxes. Impervious to cold, some frost giants wear nothing more than animal skins, although warriors often don chain shirts and decorative helmets of their own design.

Type: Evil Humanoid (Frost Giant)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d12+2, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d8, Common Knowledge d4, Fighting d8, Intimidation d8, Notice d8

Pace: 7; Parry: 6 or 5 (greataxe); Toughness: 15 (4)

Edges: Sweep

Gear: Large greataxe (Str+d10, AP 3), chain shirt (+3).

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +1: Icy skin.
  • Environmental Weakness: Fire.
  • Immunity: Cold.
  • Rock Throwing: Giants are exceptionally good at throwing rocks, and can even throw at Extreme Range. Damage Str+d12, Range 20/40/80, Heavy Weapon.
  • Size 4 (Large): 15' tall, +1 Wound.

Languages: Common, Giant.

Hill Giant.name: Hill Giant
Hill Giant.text:
Hill Giant

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Hill Giant]{Link to Actor}

Hill giants are the most nomadic of all giantkind. They usually travel in small clans, looking for easy pillaging among other humanoid settlements. Many hill giants roam the frontier of Varisia, especially in the Storval Plateau.

Hill giants look much like humans, just a lot bigger. They are around 10 feet tall and weigh 1,100 pounds. These selfish brutes tend to solve all of their problems with violence. They like to hit things hard.

Type: Evil Humanoid (Hill Giant)

Attributes: Agility d4, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d12+1, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d6, Common Knowledge d4, Fighting d8, Notice d6, Persuasion d4, Stealth d4

Pace: 7; Parry: 6; Toughness: 13 (4)

Edges: Sweep

Gear: Maul (Str+d10, AP 2), hide armor (+2).

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Leathery Skin.
  • Rock Throwing: Giants are exceptionally good at throwing rocks, and can even throw at Extreme Range. Damage Str+d12, Range 20/40/80, Heavy Weapon.
  • Size 2: 10' tall

Languages: Giant.

Stone Giant.name: Stone Giant
Stone Giant.text:
Stone Giant

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Stone Giant]{Link to Actor}

This breed of giantkind has dark granite skin, with sharp, angular facial features. They blend in easily with natural stone surroundings. Stone giants are usually 12 feet tall and weigh around 1500 pounds.

Like their rival hill giant cousins, many stone giants live in the Storval Plateau of Varisia. Some dwell in Tusk and Kodar mountain ranges to the north. They divide themselves into two primary societies: so-called “high culture” and “low culture” philosophies. The Rune Road giants adopt Thassilonian knowledge, which is considered taboo by the low culture adherents who swear by the old ways.

Type: Neutral Humanoid (Stone Giant)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6, Spirit d6, Strength d12+2, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d8, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d8, Notice d8, Persuasion d6, Stealth d8

Pace: 7; Parry: 6; Toughness: 13 (3)

Edges: Sweep

Gear: Maul (Str+d10, AP 2).

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +3: Granite flesh.
  • Resilient: Stone giants can take one Wound before they’re Incapacitated.
  • Rock Throwing: Giants are exceptionally good at throwing rocks, and can even throw at Extreme Range. Damage Str+d12, Range 20/40/80, Heavy Weapon.
  • Size 3: 12’ tall.

Languages: Common, Giant.

Storm Giant.name: Storm Giant
Storm Giant.text:
Storm Giant

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Storm Giant]{Link to Actor}

Storm giants tend toward tanned complexions, though some rare specimens have violet skin, deep violet or blue-black hair, and silvery gray or purple eyes. Such violet coloration is considered to be good luck among storm giants, and those possessing it tend to become leaders among their kind .Adults typically stand 21 feet tall and weigh almost 12,000 pounds.

Storm giants tend to be reclusive, preferring to dwell along remote coastlines or on tropical islands. They are prone to violent mood swings, and are quick to anger in the face of evil. They are brutal and dangerous foes when insulted.

Type: Good Humanoid (Storm Giant)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d6, Spirit d10, Strength d12+6, Vigor d12+1

Skills: Athletics d8, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d10, Intimidation d10, Notice d8, Performance d6, Persuasion d4, Stealth d4

Pace: 8; Parry: 7; Toughness: 18 (4)

Edges: Frenzy, Sweep

Gear: Masterwork giant greatsword (Str+d10, AP 3), masterwork composite longbow (Range 12/24/48, Damage Str+d6, AP 2), chain shirt (+3).

Powers: Burst (lightning bolt, Stream Template, use Spirit as arcane skill). Power Points: 10.

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +1: Tough skin.
  • Aquatic: Storm giants swim at Pace 7.
  • Control Weather: A storm giant can concentrate for 10 minutes to summon and control any type of weather with appropriate effects (GM's call) within a two mile radius.
  • Immunity: Electricity.
  • Innate Powers: Minor fly (levitate up and down only).
  • Rock Throwing: Giants are exceptionally good at throwing rocks, and can even throw at Extreme Range. Damage Str+d12, Range 20/40/80, Heavy Weapon.
  • Size 6 (Large): 22' tall, +1 Wound.

Languages: Auran, Common, Draconic, Giant.

Taiga Giant.name: Taiga Giant
Taiga Giant.text:
Taiga Giant

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Taiga Giant]{Link to Actor}

These nomadic hunters wander the northern reaches of Avistan and Casmaron. They patiently follow herds of auroch, mammoths, and other creatures. They usually avoid humanoid settlements, although they sometimes raid towns or villages when prey is scarce.

Large even for giantkind—20 feet tall and almost 10,000 pounds­—taiga giants decorate themselves with tattoos, jewelry, and spirit fetishes. They are fond of music and song.

Type: Neutral Humanoid (Taiga Giant)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6, Spirit d8, Strength d12+3, Vigor d12

Skills: Athletics d8, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d8, Notice d6, Occult d6, Stealth d4, Survival d10

Pace: 6; Parry: 6; Toughness: 15 (2)

Edges: Sweep

Gear: Massive spear (Str+d10), hide armor (+2).

Special Abilities:

  • Immunity: Illusion, puppet, slumber.
  • Rock Throwing: Giants are exceptionally good at throwing rocks, and can even throw at Extreme Range. Damage Str+d12, Range 20/40/80, Heavy Weapon.
  • Size 5 (Large): 20' tall, +1 Wound.
  • Spirit Summoning: Once per day a taiga giant may spend 10 minutes performing this ritual. Once completed, attacks targeting the giant suffer a –2 penalty for 24 hours. In addition, the giant gains one of the following benefits for 24 hours: boost Fighting, boost Spirit, detect arcana, or environmental resistance (cold and heat).

Languages: Common, Giant.

Barghest.name: Barghest
Barghest.text:
Barghest

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Barghest]{Link to Actor}

The four-legged barghest is likely related to the goblinoids of Golarion. In its natural state this evil hybrid resembles a cross between a wolf and a goblin—and it can assume the form of either.

Barghests come to the material @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04theplanes00000]{plane} to feed on the flesh and souls of mortals, especially humanoids. They have a connection with Lamashtu and often ally themselves with other followers of the goddess.

Type: Evil Outsider (Barghest)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6, Spirit d8, Strength d10, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d8, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d8, Intimidation d8, Notice d8, Spellcasting d6, Stealth d8, Survival d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 6; Toughness: 9 (3)

Edges: Arcane Background (Magic), First Strike

Powers: Deflection, puppet, teleport. Power Points: 10.

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +3: Fiendish hide.
  • Bite/Claws: Str+d6.
  • Darkvision: Barghests ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Hardy: A second Shaken result doesn't cause a Wound.
  • Innate Powers: Minor fly (levitate up or down only), minor shape change (goblin or wolf).

Languages: Common, Goblin, Infernal

Wild Card Barghest, greater

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Barghest, greater]{Link to Actor}

Having consumed enough flesh and souls, a few barghest return to the Abyss where they transform into greater barghests. Even fewer return to the material plan to feast yet again.

Type: Evil Outsider (Barghest, Greater)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d10, Spirit d10, Strength d12+1, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d10, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d10, Intimidation d8, Notice d8, Persuasion d8, Spellcasting d8, Stealth d6, Survival d8

Pace: 7; Parry: 7; Toughness: 12 (4)

Edges: Arcane Background (Magic), First Strike, Frenzy

Powers: Boost Trait, deflection, growth, puppet, teleport. Power Points: 15.

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +4: Fiendish hide.
  • Bite/Claws: Str+d8, AP 2.
  • Darkvision: Greater barghests ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10".
  • Environmental Weakness: Magic weapons.
  • Hardy: A second Shaken result doesn't cause a Wound to a greater barghest.
  • Innate Powers: Minor fly (levitate up or down only), minor invisibility, minor shape change (goblin or wolf).
  • Size 1: Greater Barghests are massive creatures that average 400 lbs.

Languages: Common, Goblin, Infernal.

Giant Animals.name: Giant Animals
Giant Animals.text:
Giant Animals

A wide variety of fauna exists on Golarion—some creatures grow to gigantic proportions relative to their normal-sized cousins. This section highlights several dangerous examples of giant animals or vermin found in the wilderness or underground.

Giant Ant.name: Giant Ant
Giant Ant.text:
Giant Ant

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Giant Ant]{Link to Actor}

These insects look much like their smaller relatives, but they can grow to the size of small ponies. A giant ant mound is the size of a human village.

Type: Neutral Vermin (Giant Ant)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d6, Notice d8, Stealth d4, Survival d6

Pace: 8; Parry: 5; Toughness: 8 (2)

Edges: Formation Fighter

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Chitinous hide.
  • Bite: Str+d4.
  • Darkvision: Ants ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Hardy: The creature doesn't suffer a Wound from being Shaken twice.
  • Mindless: Immune to puppet, Intimidation, and Taunt.
  • Poison (–2): The ant’s stinger contains a Mild poison.
  • Sting: Str+d4.
  • Wall Walker: Giant ants can walk on vertical or inverted surfaces at their full Pace, and may run.

Giant Centipede.name: Giant Centipede
Giant Centipede.text:
Giant Centipede

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Giant Centipede]{Link to Actor}

These long, segmented predators are as long as a man is tall. They attack almost any local fauna—including humanoids—with venomous mandibles.

Type: Neutral Vermin (Giant Centipede)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d6, Notice d6, Stealth d6, Survival d6

Pace: 7; Parry: 5; Toughness: 7 (2)

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Chitinous hide.
  • Bite: Str+d4.
  • Darkvision: Centipedes ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Mindless: Immune to puppet, Intimidation, and Taunt.
  • Poison: The centipede's bite contains a Lethal poison.
  • Wall Walker: These carnivores can walk on vertical or inverted surfaces at their full Pace, and may run.

Giant Crab.name: Giant Crab
Giant Crab.text:
Giant Crab

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Giant Crab]{Link to Actor}

This profile serves for any number of giant crustaceans, from hermits to hardshells.

Type: Neutral Vermin (Giant Crab)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d12, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d10, Notice d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 7; Toughness: 10 (3)

  • Aquatic: Pace 5.

  • Darkvision: Giant crabs ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Mindless: Immune to puppet, Intimidation, and Taunt.

Giant Leech.name: Giant Leech
Giant Leech.text:
Giant Leech

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Giant Leech]{Link to Actor}

While some folks believe their smaller cousins have medicinal value, giant leeches are dangerous vermin. As big as humans, they can latch on to an enemy with their circular row of teeth and drain all its blood. They lurk in murky waters anywhere on Golarion.

Type: Neutral Vermin (Giant Leech)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d4, Fighting d6, Notice d6, Stealth d6

Pace: 1; Parry: 5; Toughness: 6

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Aquatic: Pace 4; +2 Stealth in swamps.
  • Blindsense: Ignores invisibility and all Illumination penalties.
  • Bloodsucker: Anyone hit by a giant leech takes a level of Fatigue unless completely covered in armor with a natural bonus of +3 or more. The leech remains attached after the attack and is Vulnerable. On its subsequent turns, it automatically causes another level of Fatigue until it or its victim is Incapacitated.
  • Hardy: A giant leech doesn’t suffer a Wound from being Shaken twice.
  • Mindless: Immune to puppet, Intimidation, and Taunt.

Giant Lizard

This profile represents various giant lizards, from geckos to iguanas.

Giant Mosquito

Giant Scorpion

Basilisks live in nearly any terrestrial environment, from forest to desert. Their hides tend to match and reflect their surroundings—a desert-dwelling basilisk might be tan or brown, while one that lives in a forest is bright or dark green. Gnoll.name: Gnoll
Gnoll.text:
Gnoll

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Gnoll]{Link to Actor}

Sometimes called hyenafolk, gnolls stand roughly a head taller than humans. These vicious creatures have double-jointed legs of hyenas, with torsos and prehensile hands of humans. Their normal upright posture is humanoid though they drop to all fours when it suits them. Their heads and facial features— with short muzzles, furry ears and powerful jaws— are distinctly hyena-like.

Organizing themselves into packs, gnolls survive through raiding, hunting, and scavenging. They prefer warm climes, particularly the plains and deserts of Garund and Casmaron. Gnolls rarely form settlements or make attempts to alter their environments. They stay on the move, hunting, raiding, and sometimes taking humanoid slaves. It’s common for gnolls to keep hyenas as pets.

Goblin

These short, evil humanoids have pointed ears, wide mouths, and sinewy arms too long for their bodies. Tribal creatures, Goblins usually live underground in dark caves or long-forgotten ruins. They form war bands ruled by the strongest or smartest of the group.

Goblin tribes survive by raiding nearby settlements and waylaying travelers on the road, and then moving along once their pillaging leaves little left to steal or despoil.

Golem.name: Golem
Golem.text:
Golem

Golems are magically created automatons of great power. Unlike other constructs, golems are granted their magical life via an elemental spirit. The process of creating a golem binds the spirit to the artificial body, merging it with this specially prepared vessel and subjecting it to the will of the golem’s creator.

Being mindless, golems do nothing without orders from their creators. They follow instructions explicitly and are incapable of complex strategy or tactics. A golem’s creator can command it within 10” (20 yards). A golem usually follows its last instruction to the best of its ability. If attacked it returns the attack.

The creator can give the golem a simple command to govern its actions in his absence—or can order the golem to obey the commands of another. The golem’s creator can always resume control by issuing a new command.

Hag.name: Hag
Hag.text:
Hag

Hags are evil crones who prey on humanoids for vicious and vile purposes. All hags despise beauty, virtue, and purity. They seek to corrupt, despoil, and torment humanoid societies on Golarion.

Common Abilities

Annis hags dwell in dark caves, tangled hollows, and cursed ruins deep within frozen swamps or icy moors. They stalk forth by night to sow fear and hunt the unwary, using their disguise to lure victims into a false sense of security before attacking. Green hags haunt foul swamps and dark, tangled forests. They delight in murdering innocents, unhinging noble minds, and debasing the pure of heart. These crones are particularly fond of using disguise to assume the forms of alluring young maidens and then seducing young men away from their lovers or families. Sometimes they do this merely for spite, other times they have malevolent plans to infect and ruin entire settlements.

Harpies have feathers instead of hair. Their hands and feet bear the flesh-ripping talons of predatory avians. These creatures are known for their overpowering musk—they are usually smelled before they are seen. They sometimes wear perfumes to cover their natural odors.

Harpies live in temperate mountain areas of the Inner Sea region. They prefer craggy rookeries overlooking bogs and marshlands. They relish the “taste” of their prey’s fear and pain. Harpies tend to “play” with their food, especially favoring humans and elves.

When in packs, these creatures prefer to surround prey, with one or two using their fiery breath to force opponents into the rest of the pack.

Most hobgoblins live in military-style communities in the wilds, favoring hilly regions, especially in Avistan, Andoran, and Tian Xia. Soldiers have high status in all Hobgoblin strongholds, as warfare is their primary means of survival. These creatures raid and pillage nearby settlements, often taking slaves along with their plunder.

Hydra

Multiple angry snake-like heads rise from the sleek, serpentine body of this terrifying monster. Legends describe hydras with five to twelve heads, although the most common have seven. Tales of some fire-breathing specimens strike fear into the hearts of those who encounter them.

These solitary carnivores usually live in swamps and marshes, although some are rumored to lair in coastal reefs. Found primarily on Avistan, Casmarond, and Garund, hydra have a voracious appetite. They hunt and devour large prey whenever possible, but will feed on vermin and other animals—including humanoids—anytime the opportunity presents itself.

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Intellect Devourer]{Link to Actor}

Thought by some to be invaders from another dimension or planet, the sinister intellect devourers are certainly one of the world’s cruelest races. Incapable of experiencing emotions or wallowing in the sins of physical pleasure on their own, intellect devourers are forced to steal bodies in order to indulge their gluttony, lust, and cruelty.

Stories tell of entire cities of these creatures deep underground, where host bodies are worn like clothes to hideous orgies and vile feasts. Lone intellect devourers often dwell in ruins or caves on the edge of a civilized region so they can make periodic forays into town to “shop” for an attractive new body.

Type: Evil Aberration (Intellect Devourer)

Attributes: Agility d12, Smarts d8, Spirit d8, Strength d6, Vigor d12

Skills: Athletics d6, Common Knowledge d8, Fighting d8, Notice d10, Persuasion d6, Spellcasting d10, Stealth d12

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Aberrant hide.
  • Blindsense: Intellect devourers ignore invisibility, illusion, and all Illumination penalties.
  • Body Thief: As a limited action, an intellect devourer can reduce its size, crawl into the mouth of a helpless or recently dead creature (no more than one day), and burrow into the victim’s skull to devour its brain. This causes four Wounds that can be soaked. If the victim is slain (or already dead), the creature usurps control of the body and may use it as its own. Otherwise the intellect devoured is ejected.

    While in control, the devourer has access to the host’s abilities, except Arcane Backgrounds and Innate or Mystic Powers (it can still use its own Innate Powers, however). It knows (and can speak) the languages known by the victim and basic information about the victim’s identity and personality, yet has none of its specific memories or knowledge.

    The host decays to uselessness in seven days (unless magically preserved). If this happens or the host body is slain, the intellect devourer is ejected. Onc ejected, the devourer is stunned.

  • Environmental Weakness: Adamantine and magic weapons.
  • Immunity: Fire, empathy, puppet, slumber.
  • Innate Powers: Minor confusion, minor detect arcana , minor invisibility, major mind link, major shrink (self), minor stun.
  • Resilient: Intellect devourers can take one extra Wound before they're Incapacitated.
  • Size –2 (Small): An intellect devourer is 3 feet long and weighs about 60 pounds.

Languages: Undercommon (can't speak).

Kobolds dwell in various regions of Golarion, most commonly in Andoran but also in other nations from Cheliax to Absalom. Their underground tunnels and cave systems are known to contain many traps designed to discourage intruders or capture small prey.

Lycanthrope

Curse of Lycanthropy

Often called a curse, lycanthropy is an infectious disease. Anyone @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a naturally-born lycanthrope must succeed at a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll or contract the disease.

A creature that catches lycanthropy displays no immediate symptoms. The infected doesn't gain any of the profile's abilities until the night of the next full moon when the victim involuntarily assumes animal form and forgets his or her own identity.

The character remains in animal form until the next dawn. He remembers nothing about the entire episode (or subsequent episodes) unless he succeeds with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Spirit} roll at –2, in which case he becomes aware of his condition.

Success with the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Healing]{healing} power and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Neutralize Disease} modifier cures the affliction if applied within the first hour after being infected. With a raise, the power cures the disease within the first full 24 hours.

Consuming a potion of wolfsbane, created with a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Survival]{Survival} roll at –2, within an hour of being infected gives an afflicted lycanthrope an additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} check to recover from the disease.

See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary-journal.swpfbest00keywor.JournalEntryPage.00becomingalyc00]{Becoming a Lycanthrope} for more information about characters contracting this disease.

Several types of were-creatures exist on Golarion, from werebears to weretigers. The Inner Sea region is known as a particular hub of activity, from the Darkmoon Vale in Andoran to Wolf’s Ear in Varisia. Were-creatures often join together in secret guilds or other lycanthrope societies.

Bird of Prey.name: Bird of Prey
Bird of Prey.text:
Bird of Prey

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Bird of Prey]{Link to Actor}

This profile covers eagles, hawks, and similar large birds of prey, collectively termed “raptors.” Their talons and hooked-beaks can rip through flesh with ease.

These nocturnal or diurnal hunters sometimes serve humanoid masters on Golarion. They prefer to seize and carry off smaller quarry, although some are known to attack livestock.

Type: Neutral Animal (Bird of Prey)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d4−2, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d6, Notice d10, Stealth d8

Pace: 3; Parry: 5; Toughness: 3

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Bite/Claws: Str+d4.
  • Flight: Pace 24.
  • Low Light Vision: Birds of Prey ignore penalties for Dim and Dark Illumination.
  • Size −2 (Small): Falcons, eagles, and owls stand about 3’ tall with wingspans of 5’ or more.

Wild CardBlack pudding

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Black pudding]{Link to Actor}

Somewhat common on Golarion, these dreaded oozes inhabit caves and tunnels from Varisia to the Darklands. They scavenge for organic material, consuming all manner of refuse but also attacking creatures—especially creatures that possess metallic substances.

Black pudding can reproduce by breaking off pieces of themselves, which grow over a month’s time into a full-sized creature. They appear as dark, amorphous blobs but can alter their shape to fit into tight spaces, and to attack with their ability to envelop an opponent.

Type: Neutral Ooze (Black Pudding)

Attributes: Agility d4, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d8, Vigor d12

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d8, Stealth d4

Pace: 5; Parry: 6; Toughness: 13

Edges: –

Special Abilities:

  • Acid Form: When a black pudding hits non-magical armor, or a non-magical weapon hits a black pudding, it suffers acid damage. This reduces a weapon's total damage by 1 (to a maximum of –3). Armor loses 1 point of Armor bonus until it reaches 0 and falls apart. Weapons and armor can be Repaired with an hour’s work per point of damage or armor bonus lost, a Repair roll, and appropriate resources and tools (and a forge if working with iron).
  • Acid Strike: Str+d6.
  • Envelop: Black puddings grapple their foes with elastic psuedopods that add +2 to their grappling attempts. They can't crush foes, but automatically cause 2d6 acid damage on their action to any Bound or Entangled prey.
  • Immunity: Acid.
  • Ooze: Ignores invisibility and Illumination penalties; immune to poison, paralysis, slumber, Stun, blind, Intimidation, Taunt, puppet; doesn't sleep.
  • Size 5 (Large): These amorphous blobs can fill a space of roughly 40 cubic yards. They can take one extra Wound.
  • Split: Black puddings split into two smaller puddings when Wounded by edged or piercing weapons. These smaller black puddings are not Wild Cards, are Resilient, and use the same profile except for the following changes: Strength d6, Vigor d6, Size 2, and Toughness 7.
  • Swat: Ignores 4 points of Scale penalties.
  • Wall Walker: The pudding can cling to vertical and inverted surfaces, and move at their standard Pace.

Wererat (Hybrid Form).name: Wererat (Hybrid Form)
Wererat (Hybrid Form).text:
Wererat (Hybrid Form)

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Wererat (Hybrid Form)]{Link to Actor}

Whether naturally born or cursed with lyncanthropy, wererats are shapechangers feared by anyone with common sense. They tend to keep their abilities a secret known only to others in their hidden guilds.

Natural wererats usually look like short and wiry humans—often with a nervous disposition and darting rodent-like eyes—when in human form. Those cursed with this existence appear exactly as they did before they became infected. Both can take a hybrid form as well as that of a giant rat.

Type: Evil Humanoid (Wererat, Hyrbid Form)

Attributes: Agility d10, Smarts d4, Spirit d8, Strength d8, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d8, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d8, Notice d10, Persuasion d4, Stealth d8

Pace: 6; Parry: 6; Toughness: 9 (2)

Edges: Dodge

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Thick hide.
  • Bite/Claws: Str+d6
  • Change Shape: As a limited action, a wererat can assume one of three forms: dire rat, hybrid, or original form.
  • Environmental Weakness: Silver.
  • Fast Regeneration: Lycanthropes may attempt a natural healing roll every round unless the Wounds were caused by silvered objects.
  • Fear (–1): Wererats chill the blood of all who see them.
  • Infection: Anyone Wounded by a naturally-born wererat’s bite must make a Vigor roll or contract lycanthropy (see page 82).
  • Low Light Vision: Lycanthropes ignore penalties for Dim and Dark Illumination.
  • Size 1: Wererats are stout creatures.

Languages: Common.

Rat, Dire.name: Rat, Dire
Rat, Dire.text:
Rat, Dire

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Rat, Dire]{Link to Actor}

As big as dogs and wolves, these omnivorous creatures are dangerous if cornered or defending their nests. They tend to move and scavenge in small packs.

Type: Neutral Animal (Rat, Dire)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d6, Notice d8, Stealth d8, Survival d6

Pace: 7; Parry: 5; Toughness: 4

Edges: Acrobat, Alertness

Special Abilities:

  • Bite: Str+d4.
  • Infection: Dire rats often bear a disease (GM’s call for type and severity).
  • Low Light Vision: Dire rats ignore penalties for Dim and Dark Illumination.
  • Size –1: Dire rats grow to 5 feet long and 50 pounds.

Werewolf (Hybrid Form).name: Werewolf (Hybrid Form)
Werewolf (Hybrid Form).text:
Werewolf (Hybrid Form)

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Werewolf (Hybrid Form)]{Link to Actor}

In their humanoid form, natural werewolves look like normal people, though some tend to look a bit feral and have wild hair. Eyebrows that grow together, index fingers longer than the middle fingers, and strange birthmarks on the palm of the hand are all commonly accepted indications of a werewolf.

Of all the lycanthropes, the werewolf is the most widespread and the most feared. Stories of werewolves haunting lonely forest roads, prowling misty moors on the outskirts of rural societies, or dwelling in the shadows of the largest cities are quite common.

Type: Evil Humanoid (Werewolf, Hybrid Form)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4, Spirit d8,
Strength d10, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d8, Common Knowledge d8, Fighting d8, Intimidation d8, Notice d10, Stealth d10, Survival d10

Pace: 8; Parry: 6; Toughness: 9 (2)

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Thick hide.
  • Bite/Claws: Str+d6, AP 2.
  • Change Shape: As a limited action, this lycanthrope can assume one of three forms: dire wolf, hybrid, or original form.
  • Fast Regeneration: Lycanthropes may attempt a natural healing roll every round unless the Wounds were caused by silvered objects.
  • Environmental Weakness: Silver.
  • Fear (−2): Were­wolves chill the blood of all who see them.
  • Infection: Anyone Wounded by a naturally-born werewolf’s bite must make a Vigor roll or contract lycanthropy (see page 8).
  • Low Light Vision: Lycanthropes ignore penalties for Dim and Dark Illumination.
  • Size 1: Werewolves are stout creatures.

Languages: Common.

Becoming A Lycanthrope

When a character becomes a lycanthrope, he develops the ability to change into multiple forms (listed with each type).

Each form also has the following Special Abilities:

  • Change Shape: As a limited action, a lycanthrope can assume one of three forms: animal, hybrid, or original.

Animal Form: Use the dire creature profile.

Hybrid Form: Use the original profile with the following adjustments:

Attributes: Increase these attributes by one die type—Spirit, Strength, and Vigor.

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Thick hide.
  • Bite/Claws: Str+d6.
  • Environmental Weakness: Silver.
  • Fast Regeneration: Lycanthropes may attempt a natural healing roll every round unless the Wounds were caused by silvered objects.
  • Low Light Vision: Lycanthropes ignore penalties for Dim and Dark Illumination.
  • Size +1: They hybrid form is one Size larger than the original.

Original: Use the original creature's profile with the Shape Change ability.

Wolf, Dire.name: Wolf, Dire
Wolf, Dire.text:
Wolf, Dire

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Wolf, Dire]{Link to Actor}

These large and feral canines are often used by orcs as attack dogs. They may also be found roaming in packs in the deepest, darkest woods.

Type: Neutral Animal (Wolf, Dire)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d10, Vigor d8

Manticore.name: Manticore
Manticore.text:
Manticore

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Manticore]{Link to Actor}

A manticore has the body of a lion, the wings of a dragon, and a vaguely human head. Its mouth contains rows of razor sharp teeth and its tail ends in a ball of darts or spines.

Manticores inhabit many wild areas of Golarion, favoring the hills of Glenebon and the Mwangi Expanse, as well as the hinterlands of Varisia. For unknown reasons, they also gravitate towards forests where Darkwood grows.

These fierce and thoroughly evil predators devour every part of their victims, even their gear.

Type: Evil Magical Beast (Manticore)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6, Spirit d8, Strength d12, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d8, Intimidation d6, Notice d8, Shooting d8, Stealth d6, Survival d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 7; Toughness: 10 (1)

Edges: Trademark Weapon (Spikes)

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +1: Spiny hide.
  • Bite/Claws: Str+d6, AP 2.
  • Flight: Pace 8.
  • Night Vision: Manticores ignore all penalties for Illumination.
  • Size 2: These strange creatures grow to 10 feet tall and more than 600 pounds.
  • Spikes: A manticore may fire spikes from its tail as an action (Range 12/24/48, Damage 2d6, AP 2). A typical manticore has 24 tail spikes that regrow once per day.

Languages: Common.

Medusa.name: Medusa
Medusa.text:
Medusa

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Medusa]{Link to Actor}

Medusas are human-like creatures with snakes instead of hair. All known medusas are female. At distances of 10 yards or more, a medusa can easily pass for a beautiful human if she wears something to cover her serpentine locks. Even up close it’s hard to discern her identity if she wears clothing to conceal her head and face.

Medusas use lies and disguises to get close enough to opponents to use their petrifying gaze. Sometimes they choose to play with their prey and fire arrows from a distance to lead enemies into traps. Some enjoy creating intricate decorations out of their victims, using their petrified remains as accents to their swampy lairs.

Type: Evil Monstrous Humanoid (Medusa)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d8, Spirit d8, Strength d6, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d8, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d8, Intimidation d10, Notice d10, Occult d8, Persuasion d10, Shooting d10, Stealth d8

Pace: 6; Parry: 7; Toughness: 9 (2)

Edges: Alertness, Level Headed, Marksman, Trademark Weapon (Longbow)

Gear: Dagger (Str+d4), masterwork longbow (Range 15/30/60, Damage 2d6, AP 2), quiver of 20 arrows.

Special Abilities:

  • All-Around Vision: Medusas can see in all directions. They ignore one point of Gang Up bonuses.
  • Armor +2: Monstrous flesh.
  • Bite: Str. The snake heads can bite.
  • Darkvision: The medusa ignores penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Gaze: As a limited action, the medusa can gaze at an opponent within 5” (10 yards). The victim must make a Vigor roll (–2) or be turned to stone. He can be restored with dispel at –2, though any individual caster may try only once per target.
  • Poison (–2): The snake heads’ bite contains a Lethal poison.

Languages: Common.

Mephit.name: Mephit
Mephit.text:
Mephit

Mephits are the servants of powerful elemental creatures. Key sites and locations on the elemental @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04theplanes00000]{planes} are full of mephits scurrying about on important errands or duties.

Each kind of mephit is associated with one element that defines its special abilities. This is the base profile, followed by @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08specialabili00]{Special Abilities} for each mephit.

Type: Neutral Outsider (Mephit)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d6, Notice d6, Spellcasting d8, Stealth d8

Pace: 6; Parry: 5; Toughness: 5 (2)

Edges: Arcane Background (Magic), Dodge

Powers: Varies. Power Points: 5.

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Outsider resistance.
  • Claws: Str +d4.
  • Darkvision: Mephits ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Mephit Summoning: Once per day as a limited action, a mephit can summon a mephit of the same element to aid her.
  • Size –2 (Small): Mephits are small creatures.

Air mephit.text:
Air mephit

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Air Mephit]{Link to Actor}

Air mephits are commonly found on the Plane of Air. These mephits are whimsical and prone to distraction.

Powers: Deflection.

Special Abilities:

  • Flight: Pace 10.
  • Breath Weapon (Sand): Cone Template, 2d4 damage.

Earth mephit.text:
Earth mephit

Earth mephits are commonly found on the Plane of Earth. These mephits are plodding and humorless.

Powers: Elemental Manipulation (soften earth and stone), growth.

Special Abilities:

  • Breath Weapon (Stone): Cone Template, 2d4 damage.
  • Burrow (6”): Earth mephits can burrow underground.

Fire mephit.text:
Fire mephit

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Fire Mephit]{Link to Actor}

Fire mephits are commonly found on the Plane of Fire. Fire mephits are vengeful and quick to anger.

Powers: Bolt (scorching ray), Elemental Manipulation (heat metal).

Special Abilities:

  • Environmental Weakness: Cold.
  • Breath Weapon (Fire): Cone Template, 2d4 damage.
  • Immunity: Fire.
  • Regeneration (Fire): May attempt a natural healing roll every round, even if Incapacitated, if in contact with fire.

Boar.name: Boar
Boar.text:
Boar

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Boar]{Link to Actor}

This entry covers a variety of wild scrofines. Typically, these creatures pose a danger only during their rutting season, or when defending themselves. Certain humanoids sometimes keep these omnivores as guards, warbeasts, or garbage disposals.

Type: Neutral Animal (Boar)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d8, Strength d10, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d6, Notice d6

Pace: 7; Parry: 5; Toughness: 7 (1)

Edges:­—

  • Low Light Vision: Boars ignore penalties for Dim and Dark Illumination.

  • Tusks: Str+d4 (treat as horns).

Water mephit.name: Water mephit
Water mephit.text:
Water mephit

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Water Mephit]{Link to Actor}

Water mephits are commonly found on the Plane of Water. These mephits are constant jokesters.

Powers: Bolt (acid arrow).

Special Abilities:

  • Aquatic: Pace 6.
  • Breath Weapon (Acid): Cone Template, 2d4 damage.

Mimic.name: Mimic
Mimic.text:
Mimic

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Mimic]{Link to Actor}

These aberrations can transform themselves into simulacra of man-made objects. They position themselves in places humanoids are sure to go, but remote enough where they can attack without being seen by large numbers.

Sages of occult matters debate the exact origins of this creature, though most agree it was the result of magical or alchemical experimentation. Some believe mimics hunt for sport rather than sustenance.

A typical mimic has a volume of 150 cubic feet. Legends tell of some of much greater sizes, with the ability to assume the form of houses, ships, or even entire dungeon complexes.

Type: Neutral Aberration (Mimic)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6, Spirit d8, Strength d12, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d8, Notice d10

Pace: 2; Parry: 6; Toughness: 9 (2)

Edges: Quick

Special Abilities:

  • Adhesive: A mimic exudes a thick, adhesive slime that affects any creatures or items that touch it. When it hits with a Fighting attack, it automatically grapples the victim. Likewise, when the mimic is hit by an opponent’s physical attack, it automatically grapples the attacker. Opponents can't break free while the mimic is alive, except by using a strong alcohol or universal solvent.
  • Armor +2: Stout body.
  • Bash: Str+d6, AP 2.
  • Darkvision: Mimics ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Immunity: Acid.
  • Mimic Object: A typical mimic can assume the shape of an object roughly man-sized, such as a large chest, a statue, or a door. The creature can’t substantially alter its Size.
  • Very Resilient: A mimic can take two Wounds before being Incapacitated.

Languages: Common.

Minotaur.name: Minotaur
Minotaur.text:
Minotaur

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Minotaur]{Link to Actor}

Minotaurs have massive, bull-like heads, horns, and hooves. On Golarion, minotaurs live in small tribes or solitary lairs. They typically worship Lamashtu or Rovagug. These fierce humanoids are eager for battle and they the savor the taste of their opponents’ flesh.

Most notably, minotaurs possess an uncanny ability: they never get lost. Perhaps this is a gift from Lamashtu, who legends say created the minotaur before Earthfall. Regardless, minotaurs prefer to lair in mazes, using this ability to their advantage when intruders dare to invade.

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d10, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d10, Common Knowledge d4, Intimidation d8, Notice d6, Stealth d4, Survival d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 7 or 6 (great axe); Toughness: 11 (2)

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Horns: Str+d6, AP 2.
  • Resilient: Minotaurs can take one Wound before they’re Incapacitated.
  • Size 3: Minotaurs stand around 7′ tall and have the mass of bulls.

Languages: Giant.

Mohrg.name: Mohrg
Mohrg.text:
Mohrg

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Mohrg]{Link to Actor}

Mohrgs are former serial killers whose remains returned to unlife after they were brought to justice and publicly executed for their heinous crimes.

These undead things care even less for life than they did before their own deaths. They exist solely to wreak havoc on the living. Sometimes mistaken for skeletons or zombies, they are far more dangerous than those mindless abominations. They retain some semblance of their own memories—and the delight they once took in hearing the screams of the dying.

Type: Evil Undead (Mohrg)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6, Spirit d6, Strength d12, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d8, Notice d10, Stealth d10

Pace: 6; Parry: 6; Toughness: 13 (4)

Edges: Extraction, Quick

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +4: Necrotic resistance.
  • Bash: Str+d8, AP 2.
  • Infection: Anyone slain by a mohrg raises as a zombie one round later. When a zombie is created, the mohrg may immediately make a natural healing roll from the surge of negative energy.

  • Tongue: Touch attack.
  • Undead: +2 Toughness; +2 to recover from being Shaken; no additional damage from Called Shots; ignores 1 point of Wound penalties; doesn’t breathe; immune to disease and poison; ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.

Morlock.name: Morlock
Morlock.text:
Morlock

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Morlock]{Link to Actor}

The tragic morlocks are descendants of the ancient Azlanti who escaped the death of their empire by fleeing into the Darklands. Morlocks still resemble their human forebears despite their transformation over generations underground. They have bulging eyes and wide mouths full of flesh-rending teeth. The tallest reach five feet in height, although they appear shorter because of their tendency to run on all fours.

These subterranean tribal creatures are excellent climbers and leapers. Hunting skills are most important in morlock communities. They know how to gain high ground, leaping from crags onto their prey for fast and effective attacks. Used to living and fighting in cramped underground spaces, morlocks fight well in groups. They see clearly in darkness, while bright light is their bane.

Type: Evil Monstrous Humanoid (Morlock)

Attributes: Agility d10, Smarts d4, Spirit d8, Strength d6, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d10, Fighting d6, Notice d6, Stealth d8, Survival d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 5; Toughness: 7 (1)

Edges: Formation Fighter, Quick

Gear: Club (Str+d6).

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +1: Tough hide.
  • Bite: Str+d4.
  • Darkvision: Morlocks ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Immunity: Disease and poison.
  • Pounce: If a morlock makes a Wild Attack, it adds +4 to its damage instead of +2.
  • Wall Walker: Morlocks can walk on vertical or inverted surfaces at full Pace, and may run.
  • Weakness (Light): Morlocks subtract 1 from Trait rolls requiring sight in bright light.

Languages: Undercommon.

Feral Morlock: Vigor d10 (Toughness 8 (1)), Fighting d8 (Parry 6), are Hardy.

Morlock Alpha: Strength d8, Combat Reflexes, Frenzy.

Mule

Mules are a cross between a donkey and a horse, and are usually used to haul heavy goods or pull wagons. Like any good pet, the GM should give the mule a little personality. The expression “stubborn as a mule” certainly comes to mind.

Mummy.name: Mummy

Mummy

Usually created to guard the tombs of the honored dead, mummies are ever vigilant for those who would desecrate their sacred ground. Most mummies remain loyal to their charge until they are destroyed, some mummies retain free will even in their unlife.

  • Hardy: The creature doesn't suffer a Wound from being Shaken twice.

  • Mummy Rot: Anyone Shaken or Wounded by a mummy’s attack must make a Vigor roll or contract mummy rot. This is both a curse and disease, and can only be cured if the curse is first removed. Mummy rot is a Lethal disease that requires a Vigor roll every day. The victim can't benefit from natural healing or the Healing skill while afflicted. Attempts to use healing on the character suffer –2 to the roll.
  • Undead: +2 Toughness; +2 to recover from being Shaken; no additional damage from Called Shots; ignores 1 point of Wound penalties; doesn’t breathe; immune to disease and poison; ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.

Boar, Dire.name: Boar, Dire
Boar, Dire.text:
Boar, Dire

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Boar, Dire]{Link to Actor}

Much more aggressive than their smaller kin, dire boars attack anything that approaches them.

Type: Neutral Animal (Boar, Dire)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d10, Strength d12+1, Vigor d10

  • Size 1: Larger than humans, these dire creatures may grow to 8 feet long and weigh up to 800 pounds.

Nightmare.name: Nightmare
Nightmare.text:
Nightmare

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Nightmare]{Link to Actor}

Nightmares are flaming harbingers of death. They allow only the most evil of creatures to ride them, and are never mere mounts, but rather willing partners in destruction.

This eerie horse-like creature’s skin is an inky blackness. Fire spurts from its hair and nostrils and its hooves spray sparks.

Edges: Alertness, Fleet-Footed

  • Bite: Str+d4, AP 2.
  • Breath Attack (Poison): Cone Template, Mild poison.

  • Flight: Pace 12.
  • Innate Power: Minor plane shift (self plus rider, once per day).
  • Kick: Str+d6.
  • Size 2: Size of a riding horse.

Languages: Abyssal, Infernal.

Ochre Jelly.name: Ochre Jelly
Ochre Jelly.text:
Ochre Jelly

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Ochre Jelly]{Link to Actor}

Ochre jellies are animate masses of yellow, orange, and brown protoplasm. At rest, their flat, pulsing bodies stretch out to a wide diameter. In motion, they often ball up into quivering spherical shapes and almost seem to roll as they move. In combat, they exude long, dripping pseudopods to bash opponents with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{acidic} damage.

Their malleable bodies allow them to seep through cracks and holes far smaller than the space they usually fill. Creatures dwelling below ground often attempt to seal up any such cracks to fortify their lairs against ochre jellies.

Type: Neutral Ooze (Ochre Jelly)

Attributes: Agility d4, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d8, Strength d6, Vigor d12

Skills: Athletics d4, Fighting d6, Notice d4, Stealth d4

Pace: 2; Parry: 5; Toughness: 12

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Bash: Str+d6 (acid).
  • Divide: Slashing weapons, piercing weapons, and electricity attacks do no damage to an ochre jelly. When it would be Shaken or Wounded, the creature instead splits into two identical jellies. An ochre jelly can't split more than two times before it is Incapacitated.
  • Immunity: Electricity, slashing and piercing attacks.
  • Ooze: Ignore invisibility, and all Illumination penalties; immune to poison, paralysis, slumber, Stun, blind, Intimidation, Taunt, puppet; doesn't sleep.
  • Size 4 (Large): Ochre jellies stand one-half foot tall, spreads out to a ten foot diameter, and weighs around 2,600 lbs. They can take one extra Wound.

Ogre.name: Ogre
Ogre.text:
Ogre

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Ogre]{Link to Actor}

Ogres are foul creatures known for their cruelty and viciousness. They have long arms, muscular torsos, and stumpy legs that seem far too short for their tall frames. Their small eyes and large toothsome mouths give them an odious countenance.

These tribal giantkind live in caves throughout Golarion’s mountain ranges. Ogres stand upwards of 10 feet tall and weigh roughly 650 pounds. They are more common in untamed areas, especially in the wilds of Varisia and Avistan. Ogre tribes value strength, fertility, and hunting prowess above all else. Many ogre societies worship Lamashtu.

Type: Evil Humanoid (Ogre)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d12, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d6, Common Knowledge d4, Fighting d8, Intimidation d8, Notice d6, Persuasion d4, Stealth d4

Pace: 7; Parry: 6; Toughness: 10 (2)

Hindrances: Mean

Edges: Frenzy

Gear: Great flail (Str+d8, ignore shields), thick hide vest (+2), javelin (Range 3/6/12, Damage Str+d6).

Special Abilities:

  • Ancestry (Ogre): Menacing, Night Vision, are Resilient, Size 2.

Languages: Giant.

Ogre Raider: Vigor d10 (Toughness 11 (2)), Fighting d10 (Parry 7), are Very Resilient

Ogre Torturer: Strength d12, Powerful Blow, Frenzy (Imp)

Ogre Mage, Oni.name: Ogre Mage, Oni
Ogre Mage, Oni.text:
Ogre Mage, Oni

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Ogre Mage, Oni]{Link to Actor}

Although these evil outsiders usually manifest in the form of an ogre, they are truly fiendish spirits with powerful magical abilities. They often take command of ogre tribes, pressing the brutes into servitude. They are also known to subjugate other humanoid settlements, ruling without mercy and demanding all manners of tribute.

Whatever the reason for leaving the lower @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04theplanes00000]{planes}, an ogre mage indulges its destructive lusts while on the Material @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04theplanes00000]{Plane}. They gravitate to Inner Sea region, wreaking havoc from Tian Xia to Cheliax. They usually have ornate armor and weapons, forged at the expense of whatever society they have commandeered.

Type: Evil Outsider (Ogre Mage, Oni)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6, Spirit d8, Strength d12+1, Vigor d12+1

Skills: Athletics d6, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d8, Intimidation d8, Notice d8, Occult d6, Persuasion d6, Spellcasting d8, Stealth d6

Pace: 7; Parry: 6; Toughness: 14 (4)

Edges: Arcane Background (Magic), Arcane Resistance, Frenzy

Special Abilities:

  • Flight: Pace 10.
  • Hardy: The creature doesn't suffer a Wound from being Shaken twice.
  • Innate Powers: Major darkness, minor invisibility (self only).
  • Night Vision: Ogre mages ignore all penalties for Illumination.

Ogre Spider.name: Ogre Spider
Ogre Spider.text:
Ogre Spider

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Ogre Spider]{Link to Actor}

Often as large as an elephant, an ogre spider has the thorax and legs of an arthropod, and a vaguely humanoid face. The visual effect is disturbing, to say the least.

Type: Neutral Vermin (Ogre Spider)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d12, Vigor d10

Edges: —

  • Very Resilient: Ogre spiders can take two Wounds before they’re Incapacitated.
  • Wall Walker: An ogre spider can move on vertical surfaces at full Pace. It’s too large and heavy to walk on inverted surfaces.

Orc.name: Orc
Orc.text:
Orc

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Orc]{Link to Actor}

Orcs are brutal green-skinned humanoids with pig-like features, including snouts, long teeth, and sometimes tusks. They have beady eyes and frames slightly larger than most humans.

Orcs are tribal creatures who value strength and combat ability. Their societies are usually dominated by the strongest warriors, who subjugate the meek. Orc bands raid any neighboring communities—even other orc settlements. They have foul temperaments and rarely take prisoners.

Most orcs worship Rovagug, though some follow other gods such as Lamashtu. They inhabit many areas of Golarion, usually in the Darklands.

Type: Evil Humanoid (Orc)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d8, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d6, Common Knowledge d4, Fighting d6, Intimidation d6, Notice d6, Shooting d6, Stealth d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 5; Toughness: 8 (2)

Edges: Brute

Gear: Falchion (Str+d8, AP 1), javelin (Range 4/8/16, Damage Str+d6), light leather armor (+2).

Special Abilities:

  • Ancestry (Orc): Darkvision, Size 1, Weakness (Light).
  • Weakness (Light): Orcs subtract 1 from Trait rolls requiring sight in bright light.

Languages: Common, Orc.

Orc Berserker: Vigor d8 (Toughness 9 (2)), Fighting d8 (Parry 6), are Resilient

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Orc, Berserker]{Link to Actor}

Orc Skoll: Strength d10, Riding d8, Beast Bond, wolf mount, are Very Resilient

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Orc, Skoll]{Link to Actor}

Otyugh.name: Otyugh
Otyugh.text:
Otyugh

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Otyugh]{Link to Actor}

Scholars and experts in the occult debate the origin of this strange omnivore. Whether an accident of nature or the result of a magical experiment, the scavenger is known to dwell in the swamps and sewers of Avistan and Garund. They survive on the garbage and waste of other creatures.

The large spherical body of an otyugh is dominated by its large toothy mouth. The creature has three stumpy legs and three long tentacles—two with barbs and one with numerous eyes. Although their appearance may give the impression of a mindless carrion-eater, the aberrations possess reason and the power of Common speech.

Type: Neutral Aberration (Otyugh)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d4, Spirit d6, Strength d10, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d6, Intimidation d6, Notice d8, Stealth d6, Survival d6

Pace: 4; Parry: 6; Toughness: 10 (2)

Edges: Block, First Strike, Quick

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Thick rubbery hide.
  • Bite: Str+d4, AP 2.
  • Darkvision: These creatures ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Immunity: Disease.
  • Infection: Victims Shaken or Wounded from a bite must make a Vigor roll at –2 or gain a Debilitating disease.
  • Resilient: Otyughs can take one Wound before they're Incapacitated.
  • Size 3: An average otyugh’s main body is roughly the size of a horse. Some grow even larger.
  • Tentacles: (2): Str+d4, Reach 1.

Languages: Common.

Bugbear.name: Bugbear
Bugbear.text:
Bugbear

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Bugbear]{Link to Actor}

Larger and stronger cousins of goblins, these evil, greedy humanoids resemble the animals for which they are named. The resemblance is superficial; bugbears are sapient hunters who prey on weaker humanoids.

Bugbears congregate in tribal bands, typically making lairs in the caves of mountainous regions. Often, they ally themselves with other goblinoids, usually demanding a leadership role or simply bullying weaker cronies.

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d6, Spirit d6, Strength d8, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d6, Common Knowledge d4, Fighting d6, Intimidation d6, Notice d6, Persuasion d4, Shooting d4, Stealth d8, Survival d6

Pace: 6; Parry: 5 or 6 (shield); Toughness: 9 (4)

Edges: Alertness

Gear: Flail (Str+d6, ignores shield bonus), Javelins (Range 4/8/16, Damage Str+d6), thick hide vest (+2), light shield.

  • Armor +2: Thick hide.
  • Darkvision: Bugbears ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.

Bugbear Executioner: Strength d10, Fighting d10 (Parry 7 or 9 (shield)), Intimidation d10, medium shield, Frenzy, are Resilient.

Owlbear.name: Owlbear
Owlbear.text:
Owlbear

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Owlbear]{Link to Actor}

Appearing as a cross between a giant owl and a dire bear, this magical predator is known for its ferocity and aggression.

Theories abound as to their origins. They prefer to dwell in forests but are sometimes found in the Darklands. A mated pair will fight to the death to defend their offspring.

Type: Neutral Magical Beast (Owlbear)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d8, Strength d10, Vigor d10

Edges: Alertness

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +1: Thick hide.
  • Bite/Claws: Str+d6, AP 2.
  • Grab (Imp): An owlbear may immediately make a grappling attempt (at +2) as a free action if it gets a raise on its claw attack.
  • Night Vision: These creatures ignore all penalties for Illumination.
  • Resilient: Owlbears can take one Wound before they're Incapacitated.
  • Size 2: Owlbears stand 8-10 feet tall, and weigh up to 1,500 lbs.

Phase spider.name: Phase spider
Phase spider.text:
Phase spider

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Phase spider]{Link to Actor}

This large spider-like monster has an eerie, humanoid face surrounded by a shaggy mane of fur.

Phase spiders are voracious predators from the Ethereal @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04theplanes00000]{Plane} who hunt on the Material Plane. When prey is located, the spider shifts to the Ethereal Plane to prepare an ambush. They like to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Plane Shift]{shift} to the Material Plane, bite the victim, then retreat back to the Ethereal Plane to wait for the poison to take effect.

Phase spiders are the natural enemy of another denizen of the Ethereal Plane—the xill. The two cultures have long fought a bloody war with no real prospect of a resolution anytime soon.

Type: Neutral Magical Beast (Phase Spider)

Attributes: Agility d10, Smarts d6, Spirit d6, Strength d12, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d8, Notice d6, Stealth d8

Pace: 7; Parry: 6; Toughness: 9 (2)

Edges: Quick

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Thick hide.
  • Bite: Str+d6, AP 2.
  • Ethereal Ambush: When ambushing foes on the Material Plane from the Ethereal Plane, their prey subtracts 4 from their Notice rolls to avoid Surprise.
  • Ethereal Jaunt: Phase spiders can shift from the Ethereal Plane to the Material Plane as a free action, and shift back again as an action. While on the Ethereal Plane they can be harmed only by magical attacks.
  • Night Vision: Phase spiders ignore all penalties for Illumination.
  • Poison (–2): The spider’s bite contains a Lethal poison.
  • Size 1: Phase spiders are 8 feet long and weigh about 700 lbs.
  • Wall Walker: Phase spiders move at their full Pace on walls and ceilings.

Languages: Aklo.

Pixie.name: Pixie
Pixie.text:
Pixie

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Pixie]{Link to Actor}

This tiny, whimsical-looking fey creature darts about swiftly on wildly colored gossamer wings. They look like very small humans with long pointed ears. Pixies enjoy using their magical abilities to confuse and befuddle humanoids.

Pixies usually dwell in the forests of Golarion—especially in Avistan—but are also found in the Darklands.

Type: Good Fey (Pixie)

Attributes: Agility d12, Smarts d8, Spirit d8, Strength d4, Vigor d6

Skills: Athletics d10, Common Knowledge d8, Fighting d8, Notice d6, Persuasion d8, Shooting d8, Spellcasting d8, Stealth d10

Pace: 5; Parry: 6; Toughness: 7 (4)

Edges: Arcane Background (Magic), Arcane Resistance, Dodge

Powers: Confusion, dispel, entangle, light, protection. Power Points: 15.

Gear: Pixie bow (Range 8/16/32, Damage 2d4) with 20 arrows, pixie sword (Str+d4).

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +4: Enchanted skin.
  • Fey: Ignore penalties for Dim and Dark Illumination; +4 damage from cold iron.
  • Flight: Pace 12.
  • Innate Powers: Minor invisibility (Self only).
  • Resilient: Pixies can take one Wound before they’re Incapacitated.
  • Size –2 (Small): Pixies grow to just over two feet tall and weigh around 30 lbs.
  • Special Arrows: Pixies can sprinkle pixie dust on their arrow, adding one of the following powers to the arrow: confusion, mind wipe, slumber. Use Shooting to activate the power and hit the target.

Languages: Common, Sylvan.

Wild CardPurple Worm

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Purple Worm]{Link to Actor}

These massive scavenger worms tunnel beneath the earth of Golarion, consuming almost any organic material they find. They sometimes consume gemstones and other items able to withstand the corrosive acid inside their gullets. The worms sense vibrations through the earth, detecting a walking person upwards of 200 yards.

Purple worms are notorious for swallowing their prey whole. Bards sing songs about groups of adventurers vanishing down the ravenous maw of a purple worm, screaming as they disappear one by one.

The stats below are for a monster some 50-80 feet long.

Type: Neutral Magical Beast (Purple Worm)

Attributes: Agility d6, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d10, Strength d12+5, Vigor d10

Skills: Athletics d6, Fighting d10, Notice d10

Pace: 4; Parry: 7; Toughness: 18 (2)

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +2: Scaly purple hide.
  • Bite: Str+d8, ignores shield bonuses.
  • Blindsense: Purple worms ignore penalties for Illumination. They can detect vibrations up to 200 yards.
  • Burrow (4″): These giant worms tunnel through the ground, blocked only by solid bedrock.
  • Energy Drain: A creature hit by the worm’s sting suffers Energy Drain (Strength). The victim makes a Vigor roll to resist the effect (–2 with a raise on the attack).
  • Size 9 (Huge): These worms are usually more than 50′ long and 10′ or more in diameter. They can take two extra Wounds.
  • Slam: Str. Purple worms crush prey beneath their massive bodies. Lay three Small Blast Templates adjacent to one another in a relatively straight line to represent the portion of the creature’s body used to crush. Everything within must beat the worm in an opposed Athletics versus Agility roll or take its Str as damage. Ignore Scale modifiers when making a slam attack.
  • Sting: Str+d8, AP 3, Reach 2.
  • Swallow Whole: Anyone hit by a bite attack must make an Evasion roll or be Swallowed Whole. The victim suffers one Wound at the end of his turn from the crushing gullet and acidic bile.

    If the worm is Shaken or Wounded from the inside (ignoring its Armor!), everyone inside gets an immediate Athletics roll to escape. If the worm is Shaken or Wounded from the outside, everyone inside gets an Athletics roll at –2 to escape.

    Appropriate Tests (GM's call, such as pepper in the nose, extreme nausea from a spell effect or poison, etc.) might cause the beast to cough, sneeze, or vomit. This gives everyone inside an Athletics roll to escape.

  • Swat: Ignores 4 points of Scale penalties.

Rakshasa.name: Rakshasa
Rakshasa.text:
Rakshasa

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.rakshasa]{Link to Actor}

Rakshasas are evil spirits cloaked in the guise of humanoid creatures, walking unseen among their intended prey. While in the shape of those it seeks to defile, rakshasas gorge themselves in hideous acts. Were they human, these acts of cannibalism, blasphemy, and worse would mark them as criminals condemned to the cruelest of hells.

When not in the shape of their prey, rakshasas appear as bipeds with the head of an animal. They generally possess the heads of great cats such as tigers or lions.

Although rakshasas are outsiders, they are at home on the Material @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04theplanes00000]{Plane}. They usually hunt alone, but sometimes extended families work together to take down a specific threat or ruin a mortal civilization from the inside out over the course of many generations.

Attributes: Agility d12, Smarts d6, Spirit d8, Strength d8, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d6, Common Knowledge d6, Fighting d8, Notice d10, Performance d8, Persuasion d12, Spellcasting d10, Stealth d10

Pace: 7; Parry: 6; Toughness: 11 (5)

Redcap.name: Redcap
Redcap.text:
Redcap

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Redcap]{Link to Actor}

These stumpy, misanthropic fey exist only to indulge themselves in blissful bloodletting and wanton slaughter. Like prune-faced, angry old men, they mollycoddle their own inefficiencies and miseries in gore.

Remorhaz.name: Remorhaz

Remorhaz

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Remorhaz]{Link to Actor}

This immense creature’s body is covered in chitinous plates, with dozens of centipede-like legs and a massive head. Rhinoceros.name: Rhinoceros
Rhinoceros.text:
Rhinoceros

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Rhinoceros]{Link to Actor}

Ancient even when the gods first turned their eyes to the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04theplanes00000]{Material Plane}, the aboleths have always existed apart from other mortal life, alien and cold and endlessly plotting.

They once ruled the world with vast empires, and today view most other forms of life as either food or slaves—and sometimes both. They disdain the gods and see themselves as the true masters of creation.

Anyone starting their turn adjacent to an aboleth must make a Vigor roll or lose the ability to breathe air (but gain the ability to breathe water) for 3 hours. The creature’s new “flesh” is soft and tender, reducing its Toughness by 2 as long as it persists. If the creature’s flesh isn’t kept moist, it dries quickly and the victim takes 2d8 damage every 10 minutes. Healing with the Neutralize Poison or disease Power Modifier restores an afflicted creature to normal, but immunity to disease offers no protection from this attack.

Roc.text:
Roc

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Roc]{Link to Actor}

Rocs are terrifying, legendary birds renowned for their ability to carry off elephants and other large animals. Rocs seize such prey in their massive, clawed talons and drop them from great heights before feasting on the shattered remains.

While rocs are capable of sleeping in the air as they soar across great ranges in search of food, they generally return home to the mountains to roost and procreate.

Rocs prefer rocky crags for their massive nests—places completely inaccessible by terrestrial means. Outside of mating, rocs are extremely antisocial, and may attack others of their kind in vicious aerial battles in order to establish their territorial boundaries

Roper

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Roper]{Link to Actor}

The roper is an ambush hunter. Capable of altering the coloration and shape of its body, a roper in hiding looks remarkably like a stalagmite or pillar—or even a boulder.

When moving or fighting, the roper opens one huge eye, just above a toothy mouth. Long strands of fibrous material whip from the sides of its conical body. They can attack and manipulate items with these strands.

The roper is one of the more intelligent denizens of the deep caverns of Golarion. Its intellectual curiosity is known to some scholars, though this inquisitiveness is eventually overcome by its hunger.

Rust monsters spark terror in those who live by the sword and shield. The creature subsists on the heat generated by the oxidation of metal, not only for vitality but also for protection as the energy reinvigorates their crustacean-like shells.

This fearsome monster stands on four legs. It has a strange spiked protrusion at the end of its tail, and two long, feathery antennae. Its preferred attack is to touch an opponent’s metal garments or weapons with its antennae, catalyzing the rusting process.

Some lunatics and fools desperately claim the monstrous shoggoth is nothing more than a nightmare. They’re wrong. The truth is altogether more dire. Shoggoths exist in the deepest of ocean trenches or the most remote and forgotten caverns and ruins, emerging only rarely to spread madness and destruction in their slime-caked wakes.

Spectre

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Spectre]{Link to Actor}

These translucent, incorporeal figures have faces distorted by wrath into a hideous mask. Most spectres are the remnants of murdered or evil humans, their anger preventing them from entering the afterlife. Like ghosts, spectres haunt the places of their deaths, and seek to draw others into the lonely abyss of undeath.

Spectres look much as they did in life. They are easily recognized by those who knew them. They retain a strong sense of identity, and even ancient, insane spectres generally remain coherent.

Type: Evil Undead (Spectre)

Attributes: Agility d8, Smarts d6, Spirit d8, Strength d6, Vigor d6
