Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d6, Notice d6, Stealth d8

Pace: 7; Parry: 5; Toughness: 10 (4)

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +4: Body of stone.
  • Bite/Claws: Str+d6.
  • Camouflage: Gargoyles blend with natural stone, granting them +4 to Stealth rolls in appropriate environments.
  • Darkvision: Gargoyles ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.
  • Environmental Weakness: Magic weapons.
  • Flight: Pace 9.

Languages: Common.

Gelatinous cube.name: Gelatinous cube
Gelatinous cube.text:
Gelatinous cube

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Gelatinous cube]{Link to Actor}

These mindless predators and scavengers roam the Darklands. They consume any organic material. Sometimes materials they can’t digest—such as metal or stone—remain inside the cube. This includes the possessions of past humanoid victims.

The large cubes of ooze are usually 3-4 yards per side, although they are known to grow larger and their shape is malleable as they move through tunnels and caverns.

Scholars debate the origin of the creatures. Wealthy and powerful people go to great lengths to capture and use them as guardians.

Type: Neutral Ooze (Gelatinous Cube)

Attributes: Agility d4–2, Smarts d4 (A), Spirit d6, Strength d6, Vigor d12+1

Skills: Fighting d6, Notice d4

Pace: 3; Parry: 5; Toughness: 12

Edges: —

Special Abilities:

  • Bash: Str+d6. A raise adds +2 acid damage.
  • Engulf: The cube can attempt to engulf opponents by taking no other actions in a turn but moving over other creatures. Those who don't Evade are Bound and paralyzed for d4+1 rounds. While Engulfed, the victim takes 2d6 acid damage.
  • Immunity: Electricity.
  • Ooze: Ignores invisibility and all Illumination penalties; immune to poison, paralysis, slumber, Stun, blind, Intimidation, Taunt, puppet; doesn't sleep.
  • Paralysis: A gelatinous cube secretes an anesthetizing slime. Anyone Shaken or Wounded by its bash attack must make a Vigor roll (at –2 with a raise on the attack) or be paralyzed for d4+1 rounds.
  • Resilient: A gelatinous cube can take one Wound before being Incapacitated.
  • Size 4 (Large): These creatures are at least 10’ per side and weigh several tons. They take can take one extra Wound.
  • Transparent: When motionless, gelatinous cubes are hard to see (+2 Stealth). Those who walk or fall into a cube are automatically engulfed.

Ghast.name: Ghast
Ghast.text:
Ghast

@Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Ghast]{Link to Actor}

Like their lesser kin (ghouls), these undead creatures resemble whatever humanoid form they had before coming into unlife. They are similar to @Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Ghoul]{ghouls} in most respects, though more cunning and dangerous.

Type: Evil Undead (Ghast)

Attributes: Agility d10, Smarts d8, Spirit d10, Strength d8, Vigor d8

Skills: Athletics d8, Fighting d8, Notice d8, Stealth d8

Pace: 6; Parry: 6; Toughness: 9 (1)

Edges: Frenzy

Special Abilities:

  • Armor +1: Necrotic resilience.
  • Bite/Claws: Str+d6, AP 2.
  • Greater Paralysis: Anyone Wounded by a ghast's claw or bite attack must make a Vigor roll or be Paralyzed. Elves are not immune as they are to a ghoul's paralysis.
  • Hardy: A second Shaken result in combat doesn't cause a Wound to ghasts.
  • Infection: Anyone Wounded by a ghast’s bite attack must make a Vigor roll (at –2 with a raise on the attack) or contract ghoul fever. Ghoul fever is a Lethal disease, requiring a Vigor roll each day to prevent taking a Wound. Anyone killed by ghoul fever rises from the dead at midnight, becoming a ghoul themselves.
  • Stench: The first time anyone moves adjacent to a ghast, they become Distracted as they are overcome by nausea.
  • Undead: +2 Toughness; +2 to recover from being Shaken; no additional damage from Called Shots; ignores 1 point of Wound penalties; doesn’t breathe; immune to disease and poison; ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10”.

    Languages: Common.

Designing Threats.name: Designing Threats
Designing Threats.text:
Designing Threats

Great heroes are defined by the threats they face and obstacles they overcome. This chapter provides the building blocks for monsters and other enemies the characters may encounter.

Designing Threats

Enemies and monsters can have any @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edges} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01hindrances0000]{Hindrances} the GM feels are appropriate. They are not created like player characters (though they generally have the prerequisites of any Edges, for completeness). Just give them the abilities you want them to have and spend your time and energy on the plot of the game or how best to entertain your group.

Special Abilities

All-Around Vision

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.All-Around Vision]{See ability here}

Some creatures possess the ability to see in all directions, usually because of unique physical features. Creatures with All-Around Vision ignore one point of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Gang Up} bonus.

Ancestry

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Ancestry]{See ability here}

Many humanoids have special abilities, Edges, and Hindrances common to their ancestry. Goblins have @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Darkvision]{Darkvision}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Size]{Size} –1, and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-hindrances.Greedy]{Greedy} (Major), for example. Some non-humanoids and other creature types may also have a universal set of features—such as archons, demons, and devils—when there are different versions within a creature category.

Instead of listing each of these features separately, they are listed together in one bullet in the creature’s profile, such as “Ancestry (Goblin).”

Aquatic

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Aquatic]{See ability here}

The creature is native to the water. It's a natural swimmer and cannot drown. Its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace} in water is specified after the Aquatic ability.

Armor

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Armor]{See ability here}

A creature’s Armor is written in parentheses next to its total Toughness, and already added in. Thick, leathery hide generally offers 2 points of Armor. Creatures like a stegosaurus generally have 4 or more points of protection. Supernatural creatures may have much higher Armor values. A living statue, for example, might have 8 points of Armor or more.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Armor Piercing (AP)} attacks allow an attacker to ignore a number of points of Armor equal to the weapon's AP value.

Bash

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bash]{See ability here}

Larger creatures often use their bodies or body parts to pummel their opponents during combat. See the creature’s statistics for any special effects.

Bite

See @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Natural Weapons]{Natural Weapons}

Blindsense

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Blindsense]{See ability here}

A creature with this ability can perceive its environment using non-visual senses. This includes keen sense of smell, echolocation, or the ability to sense vibrations in the ground or even in the air. They ignore @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{Invisibility}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Illusion]{Illusion}, and all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} penalties.

Breath Weapons

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Breath Weapons]{See ability here}

Most dragons and other “fire breathers” use a Cone Template for their attacks (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Area Effect Attacks}). A few specific creatures, such as @Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Blue Dragon]{blue} and @Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Black Dragon]{black} dragons, use the Stream Template instead.

Unless otherwise noted, breath attacks may be evaded (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Evasion} for more details) and take the creature’s entire turn—they can’t perform @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Actions} in the same round they make a breath attack.

Burrow

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Burrow]{See ability here}

From massive worms to sand-dwelling humanoids, many creatures are able to burrow beneath the earth and move within it.

Burrowers can tunnel underground and reappear elsewhere for devastating surprise attacks against their foes. The distance a creature can burrow on its turn is written immediately after its Burrow ability.

A burrowing creature may tunnel on its action, and may erupt from the ground at any point within its burrowing @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace} in the same turn. It can't be attacked beneath the earth unless the attacker has some means of detecting it and penetrating the intervening dirt.

Burrowing creatures erupt from beneath their foes and may take them by surprise. If the target was unaware of the burrower’s presence, the creature makes an opposed Stealth roll versus the victim’s Notice (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Attacking from Stealth} under the Stealth Core Skill for more details). Targets on Hold may attempt to interrupt an attack before it occurs if they detect it.

Burrowers can’t usually surprise a foe once their presence is known, but can still burrow for protection and mobility.

Class Abilities

When a creature has a Class Edge, the specific features of the Edge are listed in a single bullet as a reminder. A goblin warchanter, for example, has the Bard Class Edge, with all its features listed as “Class Abilities (Bard).”

Claws

See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Natural Weapons}

Common Abilities

To save space and keep the profile as clean as possible, identical Special Abilities common to all members of a particular type of creature can often be found at the start of their section.

Construct

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Construct]{See ability here}

Golems and other animated objects are collectively called “constructs.” Some are sentient beings while others are mere automatons following the will of their masters.

Whatever their origin or material, constructs have several inherent advantages over creatures of flesh and blood.

Constructs add +2 when attempting to recover from being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, ignore 1 point of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} penalties, don’t breathe or eat, are immune to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Poison} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Disease}, don’t @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{Bleed Out}, and Wounds are removed with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Repair]{Repair} instead of @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Healing]{Healing} with no @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{“Golden Hour.”}

Darkvision

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Darkvision]{See ability here}

Some creatures on Golarion possess the extraordinary ability to see without a light source. Creatures with this ability ignore penalties for Illumination up to 10” (20 yards).

Energy Drain

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Energy Drain]{See ability here}

With a successful touch or attack, a victim must make a resistance roll (usually @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor}) or lose a die type in the targeted attribute.

If the attack would reduce an attribute below d4, the victim is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} until healed or he recovers a lost die type. If the targeted attribute was Vigor, he must make a Vigor roll at the end of his next turn or perish.

Recovery: Unless slain, a victim recovers one die type every 24 hours, or if given respite with the Restoration modifier.

Elemental

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Elemental]{See ability here}

Air, earth, fire, and water form the basis of the elemental realms, wherein dwell strange, unfathomable creatures.

Elementals have bodies of pure earth, water, air, or fire and are immune to damage, effects, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}s that match their native element. They also ignore additional damage from @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shots}, ignore one point of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} penalties, don’t breathe or eat, are immune to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{disease} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{poison}, and can only be healed via magic or natural @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{Healing}.

Environmental Resistance

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Environmental Resistance]{See ability here}

The creature is resistant (but not immune) to a particular type of energy or matter such as cold, heat, electricity, cold iron, etc.

Damage from that source is reduced by 4, and the being adds +4 to resist matching @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards} and powers with a similar @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}.

Environmental Weakness

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Environmental Weakness]{See ability here}

The creature is susceptible to a particular type of energy or matter, such as cold, heat, electricity, cold iron, etc.

The creature takes +4 damage from that source, and subtracts 4 when resisting @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards} or powers with a similar @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}.

The creature takes +4 damage from matching sources, and is at –4 when resisting matching Hazards or powers with a similar Trapping.

Ethereal

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Ethereal]{See ability here}

Ghosts, shadows, will-o’-wisps, and similar intangible creatures have no form in the physical world (or can turn it on and off at will). They can become substantial and invisible (and vice-versa) as a free action, and can only be affected by magical items or weapons and supernatural powers.

Fear

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Fear]{See ability here}

Particularly frightening monsters cause Fear checks to all who see them. Some truly terrifying monsters may inflict penalties on Fear checks as well. A creature with Fear −2, for instance, causes those who see it to make their Fear checks at −2. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04fear0000000000]{Fear} for effects.

Fearless

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Fearless]{See ability here}

Mindless creatures, such as some undead, constructs, and the like, don’t suffer from the weaknesses of the mortal mind. Fearless creatures are immune to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Fear]{Fear} effects and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}. They may still be @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunted}, however (usually because it draws their attention rather than causing emotional distress).

Flight

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Flight]{See ability here}

The creature can fly at the listed @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace}. It uses its @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} to maneuver in chases or other situations.

If a creature’s Pace is at least 24, attackers subtract 1 when making attacks against it. If it’s Pace is 48 or higher, attackers subtract 2.

Gargantuan

Gargantuan creatures are those that are at least @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 12 or higher. They have Heavy Armor (not to be confused with the heavy category of personal armor), can take three additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds}, and their attacks count as @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Heavy Weapons}.

Stomp: A Gargantuan creature may stomp by using an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{area effect} template (the size of the template is determined by the GM based on the monster’s “footprint”). The attack ignores @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} modifiers and is an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{opposed} @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} vs @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Agility} roll (defenders roll individually). Those who can’t get out of the way are stomped for damage equal to the monster’s Strength damage.

Hardy

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Hardy]{See ability here}

If the beast is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, another Shaken result doesn’t cause a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}.

Horns

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Horns]{See ability here}

See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Natural Weapons}.

Immunity

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Immunity]{See ability here}

Creatures born in fire aren’t affected by heat, and a horror made of pure lightning won’t suffer from a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt} attack with an electrical @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}. Immunities are to specific types of attacks, such as fire, cold, electricity, and so on. Such creatures don’t have @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Invulnerability]{Invulnerability} (see below), they just ignore damage and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stun} results from the specific attack types named.

Other Special Abilities

The Special Abilities listed in this chapter cover a range of common characteristics for monsters and nonplayer characters. They should help Game Masters figure out how to create their own monstrous foes or convert those from other Pathfinder products.

Of course many of the creatures in this book have rare or unique Special Abilities as well. Skim through those when creating or converting monsters with similar abilities, mixing and matching as you see fit.

Infection

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Infection]{See ability here}

A vampire’s bite, a horrid creature that injects eggs into its victim’s skin, or the scratches of some vermin can all cause Infection.

A character @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a creature with Infection must make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll. Modifiers to the roll are listed in the creature’s description, as are the effects of failure.

Innate Powers

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Innate Powers]{See ability here}

Various creatures on Golarion have innate powers. These are usually magical abilities with "spell-like" effects or powers.

Activating an Innate Power is an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{action} and follows all the power's usual rules such as @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Range}, line of sight, etc

This is true even if the power normally requires an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{opposed} or attack roll. A minor bolt, for example, automatically hits its target as long as any part of it is visible and in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Range}, ignoring @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Cover}, the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Dodge]{Dodge} Edge, etc. A major @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Puppet]{puppet} ability means the victim is automatically enthralled, but can then break free as listed in that power's description.

Rolled Powers: If an ability does require a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Trait Roll}, the skill or attribute is listed in parentheses after the power, like so: invisibility (flamer; True; Spirit).

Bolt (acid arrow; Damage; Athletics).

As with other powers, a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} causes @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue}.

Duration: Innate Powers may be maintained indefinitely, but terminate instantly if the creature is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}.

Power Modifiers: Innate Powers can't use Power Modifiers unless they're listed with the ability.

Invulnerability

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Invulnerability]{See ability here}

Invulnerable creatures ignore damage as listed in their description. Unless otherwise specified, they can be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned} but not @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by other forms of damage. An ancient dark god given life by misguided cultists, for example, might only be vulnerable to relics of a rival deity.

Low Light Vision

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{See ability here}

Low Light Vision ignores penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} (not Pitch Darkness).

Lycanthropy

Lycanthropy is an infectious disease with special properties and effects. All naturally-born lycanthropes carry the disease and can infect others. Anyone Wounded by such a creature must make a Vigor roll or contract the disease See the Curse of Lyncanthropy sidebar @UUID[Compendium.swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary-journal.swpfbest00keywor.JournalEntryPage.00curseoflycan00]{here} for more details.

Mindless

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Mindless]{See ability here}

This creature is immune to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Puppet]{puppet}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt}, and any attempts to manipulate it with any abilities that @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Tests} its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Smarts}.

Natural weapons

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Natural Weapons]{See ability here}

Creatures with natural weapons such as fangs, claws, or horns may attack with any or all of them using their @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} skill. Damage is stated for character races and beasts in their various descriptions.

Creatures with natural weapons are always considered armed. This means they aren’t @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Unarmed Defender} and foes fighting with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Two Weapons} gain no advantage against them. Here are additional notes for each type of attack:

  • BITE: The creature may bite a target it has grappled (most attackers can only crush their prey, see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling}).
  • CLAWS: +2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (climbing) rolls on any rough or soft surface (not sheer steel, glass, etc.).
  • HORNS: Add +4 damage at the end of one @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} action in which it runs, moves at least 5″(10 yards), and successfully hits with its horns.

Night vision

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Night Vision]{See ability here}

Some creatures thrive in the darkest depths of the night—or in underground caverns and dungeons. Creatures with night vision ignore all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} penalties.

Pack Tactics

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Pack Tactics]{See ability here}

This creature applies its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Gang Up} bonus to damage rolls as well as the usual bonus to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}.

Paralysis

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Paralysis]{See ability here}

Paralyzing poisons are covered under Poison, below. Other creatures might paralyze their victims with magic, electricity, or other sources. Victims @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a paralyzing effect are @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned} but can't attempt to recover for d4+1 rounds (or longer if otherwise specified).

Poison

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Poison]{See ability here}

Snakes, spiders, and other creatures inject poisonous venom via bite or scratch. To do so, the thing must cause at least a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} result to the victim, who then makes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll modified by the strength of the poison (listed in parentheses after the creature’s Poison ability). Effects of failure are described in more detail in the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards} section.

Pounce

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Pounce]{See ability here}

Predators often pounce on their prey to best bring their mass and claws to bear. If a creature with pounce makes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wild Attack}, it adds +4 to its damage instead of +2 to one successful @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} attack.

Regeneration

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Regeneration]{See ability here}

Hydras, trolls, vampires, and other legendary creatures can Regenerate their injuries.

Regeneration comes in two types: Fast and Slow.

  • Fast: @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} creatures make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll every round— even after they’ve been @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Success} heals one Wound (or removes Incapacitated status), and a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} heals an additional Wound. Wounds caused by some types of damage, listed in the creature’s description, do not regenerate but may still heal naturally. Trolls cannot regenerate Wounds caused by flame, for example.
  • Slow: The creature makes a natural @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{healing} roll once per day.

Rending

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Rending Attack]{See ability here}

Some creatures have especially vicious claws or weapons. Victims @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a rending attack are bleeding and must make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action} at the beginning of their next turn.

Failure causes one Wound and the victim must make another Vigor roll next turn. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Success} means the victim doesn't suffer a Wound, but must make a Vigor roll again next turn. A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} stops the bleeding and no further rolls are required from that attack.

A successful @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Healing]{Healing} roll also stops the bleeding.

Resilient/Very Resilient

Elite "@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Extras} are tougher than usual. This might include specially bred orcs, particularly tough thugs and bodyguards, or giant and dire versions of common animals on Golarion.

Resilient Extras can take one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} before they’re @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}, Very Resilient Extras can take two. Wild Cards can’t be Resilient or Very Resilient. The abilities exist to bring select Extras a little closer to the heroes and villains who lead them.

Shape change

The specific forms a creature can change into are listed in its description. This typically takes an action and has an indefinite Duration. A creature reverts to its natural form if killed, @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}.

Size

Size grants a bonus to Toughness (or penalty for small creatures) and is a guide to the typical @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Strength} of creatures in that general range.

Size is generally based on mass, but exceptions exist for extremely large but weak creatures, small but strong beings, etc.

Scale Modifiers are explained under @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Size & Scale}.

Additional Wounds: Large creatures can take an additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}, Huge can take two, and Gargantuan three. The maximum Wound penalty is always three. This stacks with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Resilient]{Resilient/Very Resilient}.

Such creatures typically have @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Reach} equal to the additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} granted by Size.

Stun

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Stun]{See ability here}

A creature with this ability often has an electrical attack, mild toxin, mind lash, or similar @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}. When it successfully hits a character (even if it causes no damage), she must make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll minus any listed penalties or be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}.

Summon

The creature can summon another creature. This usually takes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{limited action} and may only be performed a certain number of times per day.

The creature appears within 10" (20 yards) and acts immediately on its summoner's Action Card. It remains five rounds unless otherwise noted, then returns to its original location.

A summoned creature can't summon another creature, even if it has that ability.

Swallow whole

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Swallow Whole]{See ability here}

With a successful bite attack, the victim must make an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Evasion} roll or be Swallowed Whole. At the end of the creature's subsequent turns, anyone swallowed must make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll at –2 or take a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} from the crushing gullet and acidic bile. This continues until they're freed or perish.

If the creature is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or Wounded from the inside (ignoring its Armor!), everyone inside gets an immediate @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Athletics} roll to escape. If the monster is Shaken or Wounded from the outside, the escape roll is made at –2.

Appropriate @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Tests} (GM's call, such as pepper in the nose, extreme nausea from a spell effect or poison, etc.) might cause the beast to cough, sneeze, or vomit. This gives everyone inside an Athletics roll to escape.

Swat

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Swat]{See ability here}

The monster has learned to hunt or deal with creatures smaller than itself. It ignores up 4 points of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} penalties when attacking creatures smaller than itself.

Tentacles

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Tentacles]{See ability here}

The creature has a number of “tentacle actions” specified in its description (usually 2 or 4) it may use once per turn. All of a creature's tentacle @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{actions} count as one of its three potential actions for the turn, and must stem from the tentacle in some way— usually a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling} attack (GM’s call). A giant octopus with four tentacle actions, for example, could make four attacks as one action and still have two actions left over.

If the creature is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card}, it rolls its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Die} with each tentacle action as usual.

If the being performs other actions on its turn, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunting} or casting a spell, these and the tentacle actions are affected by the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Action} penalty as usual.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling} rolls made with tentacles get a +2 bonus, and its crushing attack causes the creature’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Strength} in damage unless otherwise listed.

Severing a tentacle is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shot}. If damage exceeds the creature’s Toughness, the limb is severed and the monster is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}. If it was already @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, it takes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}.

Trample

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Trample]{See ability here}

Elephants, rhinoceroses, and other large creatures can trample smaller victims under foot when moving at least 5″ (10 yards) in a straight line. This usually applies only when the opponents are at least two @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{sizes} smaller. See the creature's description for any special conditions or effects.

The creature makes a single attack at −2 and applies it to all victims in its movement path. Those it tramples may make an attack on it after if passes if desired (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Withdrawing From Melee}), unless it has @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Extraction]{Extraction} or a similar ability.

Undead

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Undead]{See ability here}

Zombies, skeletons, and similar physical horrors are particularly difficult to destroy. In most cases, undead creatures are Evil, but there are exceptions. Below are the benefits of being such an abomination.

  • Add +2 to Toughness and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Spirit} rolls to recover from being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, ignore additional damage from @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shots}, ignore 1 point of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} penalties, don’t breathe or eat and are immune to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{disease} and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{poison}, don’t @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{Bleed Out}, ignore penalties for @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} up to 10″, and can only be healed with magical @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Healing]{Healing}.

Unstoppable

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Unstoppable]{See ability here}

The creature has strong will, magical protections, or great mass. It takes a maximum of one Wound per attack no matter how many @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} would normally be caused (after @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Soak rolls} are made). Certain Weaknesses or magic items ignore this ability, as does an attacker acting on a Joker.

Wall Walker

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Wall Walker]{See ability here}

Some creatures have the ability to walk on walls. They automatically walk on vertical or inverted surfaces.

A Wall Walker’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{movement} rate when walking on walls is its standard Pace. It may run as usual when walking on walls unless the specific creature’s text says otherwise.

Weakness

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Weakness]{See ability here}

Some creatures can only be hurt by certain substances, are debilitated by sunlight or holy symbols, or might perish immediately if affected by some holy relic, rare object, or magical item. A Weakness not covered by @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Environmental Weakness]{Environmental Weakness} is listed here along with the specific rules and conditions required to trigger it.

Types

This Bestiary categorizes creatures within Thirteen distinct Types. These broad categories are referenced in other Savage Pathfinder rules.

  • Aberration: Rare creatures with bizarre anatomy, strange abilities, or alien characteristics.
  • Animal: Any living vertebrate creature with no magical abilities and no innate language or culture. Smarts is relative to the animal world, as indicated by the (A) as a reminder of “animal intelligence.”
  • Construct: An artificially created object or creature.
  • Dragon: The family of legendary magical reptilian creatures, usually winged.
  • Fey: Supernatural creatures, usually humanoid in appearance, with connections to nature or some other fantastical realm.
  • Humanoid: Biped creatures, with a head, torso and limbs. Humanoids usually possess language and form cultures.
  • Magical Beast: Similar to Animals, creatures of this type possess some kind of magical or supernatural ability.
  • Monstrous Humanoid: Similar to Humanoids, these creatures have some monstrous features or characteristics, as well as magical or beastly abilities.
  • Ooze: Mindless amorphous creatures, Oozes consume resources and pose environmental hazards to other creature types.
  • Outsider: Although these creatures resemble other types, their origin, or perhaps their composition, comes from beyond the Material Plane.
  • Plant: Creatures composed of vegetation, different than regular plant life, which are considered objects.
  • Undead: Any once-living creature reanimated by some magical or supernatural force.
  • Vermin: Any living invertebrate creatures, from insects, to arachnids, and arthropods.

Alignment

Like characters, creatures have an alignment of either Evil, Good, or Neutral. Each creature’s alignment is listed in parenthesis after the Type.

In general, most animals, constructs and vermin are Neutral, while most aberrations, outsiders, and undead are Evil. The alignments of Magical beasts and Humanoids vary widely.

Trappings

Like powers, creature attacks and abilities often have Trappings. A red dragon gives off a fiery aura, for example, and causes additional fire damage with its claws. A white dragon has an icy aura and does cold damage with its claws.

Specific descriptions may vary, but related types should be considered the same for purposes of environmental resistance and the like. A creature that's resistant to cold is also resistant to variations of that, such as ice, frost, abilities described as freezing, etc.

Becoming a Lycanthrope.name: Becoming a Lycanthrope
Becoming a Lycanthrope.text:
Becoming A Lycanthrope

When a character becomes a lycanthrope, he develops the ability to change into multiple forms (listed with each type).

Each form also has the following @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08specialabili00]{Special Abilities}:

  • Change Shape: As a limited action, a lycanthrope can assume one of three forms: animal, hybrid, or original.

Animal Form: Use the dire creature profile.

Hybrid Form: Use the original profile with the following adjustments:

Attributes: Increase these attributes by one die type—@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Spirit, Strength, and Vigor}.

Special Abilities:

  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Armor]{Armor} +2: Thick hide.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Bite]{Bite}/@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Claws]{Claws}: Str+d6.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Environmental Weakness]{Environmental Weakness}: Silver.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Regeneration]{Fast Regeneration}: Lycanthropes may attempt a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{Natural Healing} roll every round unless the Wounds were caused by silvered objects.
  • @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Low Light Vision]{Low Light Vision}: Lycanthropes ignore penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.
  • Size +1: They hybrid form is one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Size} larger than the original.

Original: Use the original creature's profile with the Shape Change ability.

Curse of Lycanthropy.name: Curse of Lycanthropy
Curse of Lycanthropy.text:
Curse of Lycanthropy

Often called a curse, lycanthropy is an infectious disease. Anyone @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a naturally-born lycanthrope must succeed at a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll or contract the disease.

A creature that catches lycanthropy displays no immediate symptoms. The infected doesn't gain any of the profile's abilities until the night of the next full moon when the victim involuntarily assumes animal form and forgets his or her own identity.

The character remains in animal form until the next dawn. He remembers nothing about the entire episode (or subsequent episodes) unless he succeeds with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Spirit} roll at –2, in which case he becomes aware of his condition.

Success with the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Healing]{healing} power and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Neutralize Disease} modifier cures the affliction if applied within the first hour after being infected. With a raise, the power cures the disease within the first full 24 hours.

Consuming a potion of wolfsbane, created with a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Survival]{Survival} roll at –2, within an hour of being infected gives an afflicted lycanthrope an additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} check to recover from the disease.

See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary-journal.swpfbest00keywor.JournalEntryPage.00becomingalyc00]{Becoming a Lycanthrope} for more information about characters contracting this disease.

Size Table.name: Size Table
Size Table.text:
Size Table

Use the examples below to estimate the Size of creatures and vehicles not included in the Bestiary. Mass is usually enough to determine its Size and Toughness bonus, but account for overall dimensions as makes sense.

Tiny creatures have a Strength score of 1. They can’t make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Strength} roll (and therefore can’t Ace or get bonus damage). They can damage creatures with a Toughness of 1, but can only harm Small or larger beings if they swarm together (see @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-actors.Swarm]{Swarms}).

Trappings.name: Trappings
Trappings.text:
Trappings

Like powers, creature attacks and abilities often have @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trappings}. A @Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Red Dragon]{Red Dragon} gives off a fiery aura, for example, and causes additional fire damage with its claws. A white dragon has an icy aura and does cold damage with its claws.

Specific descriptions may vary, but related types should be considered the same for purposes of @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Environmental Resistance]{environmental resistance} and the like. A creature that's resistant to cold is also resistant to variations of that, such as ice, frost, abilities described as freezing, etc.

Wild Card Monsters.name: Wild Card Monsters
Wild Card Monsters.text:
Wild Card Monsters

Creatures noted with this symbol are @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Cards and Extras}. They roll a Wild Die with Trait checks and can take three @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} before being @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}.

Iconic creatures and "bosses," such as @Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Red Dragon, Adult]{adult dragons} or @Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Lich]{liches}, are almost always Wild Cards.

Named creatures are often Wild Cards as well, such as the ogre Jaagrath Kreeg in the Rise of the Runelords Adventure Path or any of his named kin.

Groups of creatures are often led by a Wild Card as well, such as a pack of @Compendium[swpf-bestiary.swpf-bestiary.Dog/Wolf]{wolves} led by a Wild Card "alpha."

Which creatures are and aren't Wild Cards is up to the GM and how challenging you want a threat to be.
